title: ELN Kolumbien - Das Leben als Guerilla ( Dokumentation)
creator: Red Media Kollektiv
description:
Das Ejército de Liberación Nacional (ELN, deutsch Nationale Befreiungsarmee) ist eine kolumbianische, marxistisch orientierte Guerillabewegung. In Bolivien existierte eine Guerillagruppe mit dem gleichen Namen.

Die ELN wurde 1964 von Fabio Vasquez Castaño gegründet und gehört somit zu den ältesten noch aktiven Guerillaorganisationen Lateinamerikas. Die Gruppe rekrutiert sich vor allem aus dem urbanen und intellektuellen Milieu und soll etwa 1500 Kämpfer unter Waffen haben. Die ELN soll über keine straffe Kommandostruktur verfügen.[2]

Sie orientierte sich anfangs an den Schriften Che Guevaras, insbesondere an der Theorie des Fokismus, d.h. des zunächst lokal begrenzten Aufstandes, der sich letztendlich als flächendeckende Revolution ausweiten soll. 1963 begann eine 16-köpfige Gruppe um den Studenten Fabio Vázquez Castaño in der Provinz Santander mit den Vorbereitungen zur Gründung eines kolumbianischen Guerilla-Fokus. Sie machte sich mit dem Terrain vertraut, organisierte die Logistik und knüpfte Kontakte zu den Veteranen der violencia, vor allem zu den aus der Region stammenden Guerilleros Rafael Rangels, der 1948 den Volksaufstand in Barrancabermeja geleitet hatte und nach seinem Rückzug in die Berge 1950 dort liberal beeinflusste Guerillagruppen gegründet hatte, die im Gebiet zwischen dem Magdalena-Strom und der venezolanischen Grenze aktiv waren. Sechs Monate nach der Gründung der ELN besetzte eine jeweils zur Hälfte aus Bauern und Studenten bestehende erste bewaffnete Gruppe im Januar 1965 die Stadt Simacota.

title: COLOMBIA: ELN REBEL LEADER MANUEL PEREZ DIES AGED 62
creator: AP Archive
description:
(7 Apr 1998) Spanish/Nat

Manuel Perez, former priest turned founder of Colombia's second-largest rebel group the National Liberation Army (E-L-N) has died.

Perez, who was 62, died of hepatitis in his secret jungle hideout.

His death comes just weeks before the start of scheduled peace negotiations with the Colombian government in June.

Manuel Perez has died after more than thirty years as the leader and mentor of Colombia's National Liberation Army (E-L-N).

The rebel E-L-N is the second largest guerrilla movement in Colombia with over four thousand members.

Ironically it was not the fighting that killed this priest turned revolutionary, but hepatitis contracted deep within the jungle.

On hearing of his death, Colombia's President Ernesto Samper praised Perez for his recent decision to negotiate peace talks.

Perez was born in Spain.

He first came to Colombia as a priest preaching to the nation's poor. 

He swapped his priest's collar for a gun and founded the rebel group in 1964 in the northern coastal town of Magdalena. 

He was defrocked when he took up arms, but was still known as "Father Perez".

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"We want to enter the negotiations with a clear objective. We are entering them saying that we are prepared enter a negotiation where the main problem is not the actual laying down of arms."
SUPER CAPTION: Father Perez, former Catholic priest turned rebel

Perez used the Cuban revolution as an inspiration for his teachings to young revolutionaries.

His rebel movement targets foreign companies who it says unfairly exploit Colombia's natural resources.

Several hundred E-L-N led attacks on oil pipelines through Colombia have been reported in recent years.

But the E-L-N has increasingly turned to kidnapping, extortion and the drug trade to fund its struggle.

As a result Colombia has the world's highest kidnapping rate, with an average of four abductions a day.

The E-L-N were due to start negotiations with the government in June after the presidential elections.

It is not known whether Perez's death will affect the planned talks.

His successor is the rebel second-in-command Nicolas Rodriguez Bautista, 47, who is known as Gabino.

title: Colombia: The long road to peace after the civil war | DW Documentary
creator: DW Documentary
description:
Is Colombia really at peace? Even three years after the peace treaty, there is no clear answer. The documentary charts the ongoing conflict between the FARC guerillas and government, which is still fueled by war and social inequality.

Bogotá, 2016: the year that will go down in Colombian history books. After some five decades of civil war, the Marxist FARC guerrillas and the government signed a historic peace agreement before eyes of the world. It could have ended not only the armed conflict, but also the yawning gap between rich and poor in Colombia. A nationwide referendum at the beginning of October 2016 was supposed to give the government democratic legitimacy for the move and approval was considered certain. But then the unbelievable happened: The Colombian population rejected the agreement with the FARC rebels by a wafer-thin majority. It was a huge shock for the South American country, where the civil war had cost at least 220,000 lives and made six million people homeless. After nationwide student demonstrations, a new, revised peace treaty was finally signed in November 2016. Filmmaker Uli Stelzner followed the dramatic events of 2016 and the difficult process of implementing the agreement. Colombia may officially be at peace, but the country still knows no rest.

title: Military commander says rebel takeover averted
creator: AP Archive
description:
(2 Aug 2002) 

July 20, 2002 Bogota 
1. Black Hawk helicopters participating in military parade
2. Armoured cars passing by
3. Special troops marching by

August 1, 2002 Bogota
4. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) General Fernando Tapias, Colombian Armed Forces commander
"If we're talking about tangible balances, I would say that over the past four years, over 22,000 members of these illegal armed groups have been put out of combat, close to 4,700 fallen in hundreds of battles, 1,700 captured and put under control of the authorities and close to 1,000 deserters of these groups. That's a big number. Even more important than this is that the military forces have been able to decommission 500 tonnes of drugs that had been or were being processed that hadn't been put on the international market.  Plus, we rescued more than 1,500 hostages, allowing 1,500 families a return to happiness.  They practically came back to life thanks to action from the military forces."
5. Cutaway of presser 
6. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) General Fernando Tapias, Colombian Armed Forces commander
"It doesn't only demand the armed forces, but it also demands public opinion, it demands the efforts of all parts of the state, of the legal field, of the economic field, of the social field, and that's why we're talking about an integral effort. The war has called on public efforts over many years, and it's created a lot of contention, but the effect is that Colombians are seeking the total return to security.  That must be reached by means of the state with the coordination and the efforts of all sectors." 
7. Cutaway of Tapias 
8. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) General Fernando Tapias, Colombian Armed Forces commander
"The Colombian state can destroy the FARC and force them to negotiate seriously because beating the FARC doesn't only imply victories in the field or in the military, it means they must be defeated especially in the area of finance. The FARC's strength isn't ideological or military. The strength of the FARC is an economic product of drug money, hostage-taking, and extortion."
9. Close-up of military badges on General Tapias' uniform
10. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) General Fernando Tapias, Colombian Armed Forces commander
"Four years ago the democratic system of Colombia was in danger.  We were not certain it would continue.  Today, we have the absolute certainty that there is no possibility that (the rebels') actions will change the system chosen by Colombians."

July 20, 2002 Bogota
11. Special military troops participating in a military parade
12. Wide shot of Colombian president Andres Pastrana and his family watching soldiers passing by

STORYLINE:

Colombia's outgoing military commander said that the army had blunted the ability of rebel groups to overthrow the government, but the insurgents will be defeated only when they are deprived of their drug trafficking income.

Army General Fernando Tapias will step down when Colombian president-elect Alvaro Uribe is inaugurated Wednesday.  He told the media that Colombia's military build-up during the current administration had secured democracy.

When Tapias took over as armed forces chief four years ago as president Andres Pastrana assumed office, the rebels were openly challenging the demoralised military.   In 1998 alone, hundreds of soldiers and police died in combat.  Now, the rebels are reduced to attacks against the country's infrastructure and trying to overwhelm isolated police posts.




Tapias warned that the war, now in its 38th year, will not end soon but maintained that peace is closer than it was when Pastrana assumed the presidency four years ago.

STORYLINE:

The Colombian Army captured three I-R-A suspects on Monday coming out of the  demilitarized zone ceded to Colombia's largest rebel Army, the FARC.

According to Army officials, the suspects have been training FARC rebels in bomb-making in the La Macarena area over the last five weeks.

APTN, after an invitation from Mono JoJoy, one of the main FARC commanders, was allowed to film in the area of La Macarena.

These images of FARC members training were taken during the time the IRA suspects were also allegedly there.

Military training exercises were witnessed by an Associated Press team during a five-day trip through a rebel safe haven and provided a rare look at the largest insurgent army in Latin America.

A who's who of Colombia's most-wanted list can be found in this and other rebel camps:

Jorge Briceno, the military commander of the FARC, who goes by the nom de guerre Mono Jojoy - or Jojoy the Blonde.

He lives in a better-appointed camp and was holding court with dozens of visitors.

Edison Romana, in charge of kidnapping hostages in Bogota for ransom, was in Campamento La Libertad, leafing through the pages of Cromos, a Bogota society magazine.

President Andres Pastrana ceded the Switzerland-sized zone to the 16,000-strong Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, in 1998 as an incentive for the rebels to engage in peace talks.

Almost three years later, the talks have produced no breakthrough. 

But critics of  the demilitarized zone say that La Macarena has become a laboratory for war instead of peace and that it was not meant for the training of troops.

Meanwhile, the rebels are using the territory for military training and seem ready to continue waging a war which is now in its 37th year.

Some 600 rebel fighters are in Campamento La Libertad, a sprawling complex of wooden barracks and makeshift tents in a forest 110 miles (180 kilometers) south of Bogota, the capital.

Most of the guerrillas are in their late-teens or early 20s  -and veterans of combat with U-S-backed government troops, bearing scars from wounds.

title: COLOMBIA: FARC PREPARE TO LAUNCH POLITICAL PARTY
creator: AP Archive
description:
(29 Apr 2000) Spanish/Nat
XFA
Colombia's biggest left-wing rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia or F-A-R-C, is preparing for the launch of its own political wing.

Thousands of guerrillas have been assembling in southern Colombia in advance of the inauguration, due to take place on Saturday.

The political body, called the Bolivarian Movement, will have anonymous membership until peace accords have been negotiated with Colombia's government.

Preparations are underway in the remote jungle town of San Vicente del Caguan prior to the inauguration of the political party of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (F-A-R-C) on Saturday.

Thousands of guerrillas left the misty jungles of southern Colombia in unprecedented numbers to come to F-A-R-C's stronghold in San Vicente del Caguan.

The  F-A-R-C is Colombia's biggest left-wing rebel group, and its political wing has been named the Bolivarian Movement, after the South American independence hero, Simon Bolivar. 

It has been suggested that this is further evidence that the F-A-R-C is ready to move away from being a purely military organisation to being a political one.

The commander of the F-A-R-C, Jorge Briceno, insisted that his organisation was engaged in a dialogue with Colombia's government

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"The political moment of the country is now. We are in dialogue with the government and now we are contributing to this process to show the world that we have a lot of interest and that we want a civilised way different to war"
SUPER CAPTION: Jorge Briceno, FARC Commander

FARC's political party demands include radical wealth distribution, sweeping agricultural reforms, and an end to unfettered free market economic policies.

Briceno remains wary of the F-A-R-C becoming an official opposition movement.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is a clandestine movement, we are taking the experiences of the UP (Union Patriotica) so we do not repeat those mistakes again because we do not have democracy in Colombia for opposition parties."
SUPER CAPTION: Jorge Briceno, FARC Commander

The party's membership will remain anonymous until it negotiates a peace accord with the government.

In the 1980s, two thousand members of the F-A-R-C's political wing were killed by right-wing death squads.

title: COLOMBIA: REBELS RELEASE 9 HOSTAGES
creator: AP Archive
description:
(28 Mar 1998) Spanish/Nat

Colombian guerrillas have released nine hostages they kidnapped last week from a highway outside the capital Bogota.

The freed hostages were released near the mountain town of El Calvario in the Meta province.

Four Americans and one Italian are still in captivity and the rebels say they'll release them as soon as they find out whether or not they have links with paramilitary groups.

The five-day ordeal is now over for this group of nine men and women.

They were among at least 18 people kidnapped by rebels with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia at a highway outside Bogota last week.

The guerrillas snatched them when army troops moved to dislodge a rebel roadblock late on Monday in a bloody confrontation in which nine people, including six guerrillas, were killed.

A rebel commander said the hostages were believed be linked with right-wing paramilitary groups.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"The actions from the guerrilla movement are part of a war by the guerrillas that will continue until we reach our objective of giving power to the people." 
Q: "What kind of proof do you have to say that these people were paramilitaries?"
A: "They have farms in Villa Nueva and Puerto Lopez and they've been financing and sponsoring paramilitary groups and that's why they were executed in the highway."
SUPER CAPTION: Commander Romaña, rebel leader Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, FARC

Although they feared for their lives, the released hostages say they weren't mistreated.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"We were treated very well, and I thank God that I can return home."
SUPER CAPTION: Alex Prieto, released hostage

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"We had pretty tough questionings as to whether we had links to paramilitaries, where we were coming from, where we were going to and that hit us hard, that they thought we were paramilitaries."
SUPER CAPTION: Luis Antonio Garcia, released hostage

The nine hostages - all Colombians - were released in the mountain town of El Calvario in the Meta province. 

They were picked up by a civilian helicopter after negotiations involving the Red Cross and other humanitarian organisations.

They could not say how many hostages were being held, but they confirmed that four Americans and one Italian were still in captivity.

Rebel leaders say that the foreigners would be released as soon as they determine whether or not they have links with the paramilitaries.

The F-A-R-C is Latin America's oldest and largest guerrilla organisation which has been waging a war against the Colombian government for over three decades.

title: COLOMBIA:  FIERCE CLASHES AFTERMATH
creator: AP Archive
description:
(13 Jul 1999) Spanish/Nat 

Fierce clashes between the Colombian army and the FARC guerrillas largely subsided on Monday, with both sides claiming victory.

Since fighting began on Thursday, at least 59 police and soldiers have been killed and the army says it killed more than 200 guerrillas.

Earlier on Monday, in a show of war propaganda, reporters were flown to one of the worst hit areas, where the Commander of the Colombian Army proudly displayed the corpses of some 30 FARC guerrillas.

Trying to convince a skeptical media, troops brought journalists to an army base where they displayed the bodies of 30 guerrillas.

They were allegedly killed in Puerto Lleras, a town 114 miles (190 kilometers) from Colombia's capital Bogota. 

Young women made up about a third of the dead on display at the army base in Granada, twenty minutes by helicopter from Puerto Lleras.

Many still had red, yellow and blue banners across the chests - national colours Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) fighters often wear into battle.

Military leaders are saying they saved the country from one of the guerrillas' most ambitious offensives since taking up arms in the 1960s.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"The Colombian Army will never allow these bandits to take power by force. It's impossible for the FARC. They must realise they will never get it".
SUPERCAPTION: General Jorge Mora, commander of the Colombian army

Many observers have their doubts. 

They feel the FARC is making steady progress - even if it lost some fighters, didn't permanently seize territory or inflict heavy government casualties in its latest offensive.

The rebels launched their offensive less than two weeks before a planned round of negotiations with the government of President Andres Pastrana to end Colombia's 35-year conflict.

The FARC is demanding sweeping reforms to attack poverty, redistribute land and clean up political corruption.

Fighting raged over the weekend in 10 of the country's 32 provinces, killing at least 59 police and soldiers as well as two children whose house was destroyed by a rebel bomb.

The army claims it killed a fifth of an estimated one-thousand rebel fighters participating in the attacks.

Puerto Lleras, a small river port in the jungles of eastern Meta province, was the scene of some of the worst clashes over the weekend.

FARC fighters stormed into the town on Saturday night and pounded the local police station with rockets and homemade missiles.

The entire village of Puerto Lleras has been looted or destroyed.

Most of the villagers, as this old woman, are left with nothing else than their despair.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"I don't really know know what to say. I don't understand why they did it. They left us in complete ruin".
SUPERCAPTION: Villager

In the town itself, army explosives experts worked to defuse homemade missiles left by the guerrillas, who flattened a police station and homes with the crude, but deadly weapons fashioned from gas canisters.

Despite the latest claims by the Colombian army, the 15-thousand member FARC has enjoyed a nearly unbroken string of victories during the past three years.

In a much larger offensive last August, the rebels killed 143 soldiers and police, took more than hundred captive and overran a major anti-narcotics base.

title: COLOMBIA: FARC REBEL GROUP RELEASE 70 SOLDIERS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(15 Jun 1997) Spanish/Nat

Colombia's main rebel group released 70 soldiers on Sunday.

The soldiers, who were freed in a carefully orchestrated ceremony, had been held for months by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).

But Sunday's release agreed by the rebels and the government was no indication of a lasting peace in the country.

The soldiers were ferried, alongside their rebel captors, to Cartagena del Chaira in Russian-made MI-17 helicopters.

The helicopters were provided by the government and the released soldiers were accompanied by International Red Cross workers.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
A: Happy with everything that's happening, thank God.
Q: Any problems during the flight?
A: No, nothing. Everything was fine."

SUPER CAPTION: Released soldier

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"Right now I can't remember very well what happened when the Delicias camp was taken.''
SUPER CAPTION: Released soldier

To facilitate the handover, President Ernesto Samper met a demand by Latin America's oldest active insurgents to demilitarise a 16,161-square-kilometre (5,080-square-mile) jungle zone including Cartagena del Chaira.

On hand for the release were half a dozen European ambassadors, as well as delegates from Costa Rica and Guatemala.

The freed soldiers, clean-shaven and in apparent good health, did not complain of mistreatment and said the guerrillas loaned them radios and sometimes permitted them to watch television. 

The worst, they said, were the insect bites.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"Great happiness for being free again."  

SUPER CAPTION: Released soldier

Sixty of the soldiers were captured in August by FARC fighters who overran a remote military outpost in nearby Las Delicias, killing 27 troops. 

It was the government's most embarrassing defeat in more than 30 years of low-level conflict.

The other 10 were captured in a January ambush in Colombia's north-west.

The FARC rebels has already kidnapped more than 60 civilians this year.

title: COLOMBIA: COCA PLANTS & COCAINE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(30 Aug 2000) Spanish/Nat
U-S President Bill Clinton arrives in Colombia later today as he introduces Plan Colombia - the 1.3 (b) billion U-S aid package aimed at fighting narcotraffickers.
Under the plan, 60 combat helicopters will escort fumigation planes and ferry U-S trained anti-narcotics troops into drug producing plantations which cover vast areas of southern Colombia. 
But for thousands of farmers the plan is threatening the very thing they depend on to survive - coca, the plant that forms the base of cocaine.
The sun rises over the Caguan River, 280 miles (470 kilometres) from the Colombian capital, Bogota. 
Nestled alongside the river is the settlement of Penas Coloradas, a grimy settlement where coca is the economy's driving force and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) - the country's oldest and largest Marxist guerrilla group.
Farmers here grow coca.
This is FARC territory. The entire process, from the growing of coca to the creation and selling of the final product - cocaine - is monitored by rebels.
Their control here is strict. Liquor sales are forbidden between Monday and Friday. Theft and drunken behavious are punished.
It's in their interest to do so. The drugs help finance their 15-thousand strong force, fuelling a civil war which is fast approaching its fourth decade.
Now, the introduction of Plan Colombia is threatening the way of life of these farmers. They are far from grateful for the U-S backed intervention.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"With this Plan Colombia, if there is so much money to be distributed, why don't they give any of it to the poor? Why don't they give the poor money if there is so much money to give?" 
SUPER CAPTION: Laura, Coca farmer
FARC leaders claim the coming offensive will provide the FARC with an ample recruiting base among farmhands who could lose their livelihoods as a result.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is our life. This is our work. Here we all work together, look, behind us, this is how we all survive."
SUPER CAPTION: Fanny, Coca farmer
FARC rebels protect the crops of coca and poppy, from which heroin is made. 
They have vowed to fight the Plan.
As two Vietnam-era planes lazily circle these fields ready to dump a load or herbicides onto the plantation, the rebels open fire with their Galil assault rifles.
The crackle of automatic weapons fire splits the afternoon silence.
Plan Colombia will see a dramatic increase in anti-narcotics flights such as these, with more helicopters and planes being provided to the country.
But rather than back away in fear of the promised increase, FARC rebels have vowed to increase kidnappings - a longtime source of income for the group - in order to raise funds to equal the Plan.
Meanwhile, the growing and selling of coca continues.
In this simple shack by the side of the river farmers bring their cultivation of coca to be weighed, tested, and bought.
This coca paste - a semi processed form of cocaine - will be sold on to international markets - generating millions of dollars.
Coca farmers insist they have no choice.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"I have a family. What I earn goes to my mother, my wife. (Q) So it's from necessity. (A) Of course, it's from necessity, if I didn't have to I wouldn't do it."
SUPER CAPTION: Coca farmer
For the farmers in Penas Coloradas as in much of the rest of impoverished, rural Colombia, there are few viable alternatives to making a living than growing coca. 
They are skeptical of government pledges that the anti-drug offensive will be accompanied by loans and other assistance to help them grow legal crops.

title: COLOMBIA: KIDNAPPED FOREIGNERS MAY BE HELD BY REBELS FOR 6 MONTHS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(29 Mar 1998) Spanish/Nat

A Colombian rebel commander who is holding four Americans and an Italian captive has warned that it could be more than six months before they are released.

Commander Romaña, local leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, said his group is investigating if the hostages are from right-wing paramilitary groups and they won't be released until that investigation is complete.

He also said the guerrillas would probably demand a ransom for their release.

The foreigners were kidnapped last Monday with a large group of Colombians during a road attack just outside Bogota.

Rebels from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia have set up a provisional camp in a remote location in the outskirts of the town of El Calvario.

They kidnapped a group of hostages last Monday near the Colombian capital, Bogota.

The guerrilla group already released nine hostages.

The others - including four Americans and an Italian - are still in captivity.  

Their leader, Commander Romaña, says that no harm would come to the remaining captives.

But he warns that the F-A-R-C  will probably demand a ransom for their release and that it could take more than six months before they are set free.

This is because Romaña says an investigation will be carried out to determine whether or not the foreigners and the remaining Colombian hostages have any links with right-wing paramilitary groups.

He predicted that the investigation could take between six months and a year.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"We're going to investigate the kidnapped foreigners - they're four men and a woman. It will probably take five, six months or a year, I don't know, until a good investigation is done, because we don't want to make a mistake."
Question: "When you talk about mistakes, what do you mean?"
Answer:  "For example, an execution without them having any links with the American authorities or with the Colombian military."
SUPER CAPTION: Commander Romaña, leader Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia

The U-S State Department has confirmed that the four Americans were on a bird-watching trip in Colombia.

But the rebels think they could have links with U-S intelligence agencies or paramilitaries.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"It's suspicious. When a person carries out an activity, that person has the material needed to do that, right? If they came to watch birds they should have brought their lenses, their tripods, their tourist identification card stating that they'll research our flora and fauna. These people came with nothing."
SUPER CAPTION: Commander Romaña, leader Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia

He claims this is not the first time foreigners - especially Americans - have tried to reach guerrilla strongholds.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"Those are areas where practically no tourists go in, and many Americans have infiltrated the areas dominated by the F-A-R-C  with the excuse of watching birds or fishing, or saying that they're professors in order to get information about the guerrilla movement."
SUPER CAPTION: Commander Romaña, leader Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia

The F-A-R-C  released nine hostages on Friday claiming they did not have links to paramilitary death squads and were not wealthy enough to be ransomed.

Commander Romaña has denounced the army for aiding paramilitaries and said the F-A-R-C  wants peace.

Colombia's number two rebel group - the National Liberation Army - signed an accord with the government last month to begin peace talks.

But the F-A-R-C  has not said whether it will join the reconciliation effort.

title: COLOMBIA: GUERRILLAS HELD RESPONSIBLE FOR ATTACK ON ARMY CONVOY
creator: AP Archive
description:
(18 Apr 1996) Spanish/Nat

The left-wing guerrilla group "Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia" (FARC) has claimed responsibility for this week's attack on an army convoy, in which 31 soldiers were killed.

Talking to APTV at their hideout, FARC rebels accused the government of declaring war on the rebels, forcing them to take harsh measures - like the ambush.

Most of the victims of the attack on the convoy have now been buried - among the mourners attending their funerals was President Ernesto Samper.

This is El Cauca department in south-west Colombia, a region where most of the people are poor and have always been disenchanted with the government.

It is here, deep in the mountains, that the "Gaitana" unit of the FARC Sixth Front has its roots and headquarters.

These are the men that led an attack on the town of Florida a month ago.

One policeman was killed and three other people were wounded.

There are women too: in the Gaitana unit alone there are 10 women fighters among the 120 guerrillas.

The hierarchy is complicated: the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia (FARC) guerrillas are divided into fronts, and these into units. 

They don't operate together, but all fronts have a common enemy.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
They have declared war on us in this country in many fronts, the government has declared war on us. That's why we have these kinds of ambushes, because we are making war. It is not that we like that 20 or 30 soldiers die. We don't laugh about it, but we take it as something necessary. There is a war going on and these are the results.
SUPER CAPTION: Comandante Carlos, Gaitana Unit, 6th front, FARC guerrilla

The FARC has been fighting the Colombian government for more than 30 years.

Their aim is "to work for the community in an armed fight for equality and democracy".

The Gaitana unit was not responsible for Tuesday's ambush in which 31 soldiers were killed, but they were interested in the television coverage of the event. 

Colombian television showed some victims' charred bodies hanging out of the destroyed vehicles and others lying in the grass along the road.

For these guerrillas, they were simply casualties of a long war against the state authority.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
We know a soldier is a peasant; a student. In the same way as we are peasants. We have already told the soldiers not to get involved in this war so that they don't suffer the consequences, because the ones we make responsible for these war are the military and the state, that order these boys to persecute the guerrilla, to get caught in an ambush.
SUPER CAPTION: Comandante Carlos, Gaitana Unit, 6th front, FARC guerrilla

One of the toughest fighters in this war is Menuel Marulanda alias "Tirofijo" - a legend among Colombia's guerrilla factions.  Despite numerous reports that he's been killed in action, Marulanda resurfaces every so often - such as in this rare appearance captured on video in 1993

Guerrillas have stepped up attacks in recent weeks taking advantage of the political crisis facing Colombia - their aim is to destabilise the government.

The Gaitana unit is ready to continue the fight. 

But in Ipiales, a town along the Ecuadorean border near the site of the rebel ambush, the victims of FARC's fight are being buried.

16 of the 31 soldiers were laid to rest - their funeral was attended by President Ernesto Samper. 

He eulogized the soldiers and pledged to search for a negotiated peace with rebels.

Even so, his administration is considering drastic measures to fight the rebels.

title: COLOMBIA: SUMAPAZ: F-A-R-C REBELS KILLED
creator: AP Archive
description:
(4 Mar 2000) Spanish/Nat

Five rebels from Colombia's largest rebel group the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia or FARC were killed and eight captured in fighting with government forces on Friday.

Among the captured rebels, a 13 year old child who said she had been coerced into fighting with the group.

The latest battle in Colombia's ongoing civil war.

Helicopters ferried these rebels from the fighting in the area of Sumapaz in Colombia.

The ragtag group of eight captured guerrillas included a child and civilians.

This young 13 year old girl told of how she had been forced into fighting for the FARC.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"I'm 13 years old
Q: How did you get brought into the guerrilla?
They forced us and told us that if we didn't join the guerrillas they would kill us and our family. 
Q: Where?
Near Pueblo Viejo.
Q: How long have you been in with the guerrillas?
8 days. 
Q: Are there many other children like you?
Two.
Q: In those 8 days did they show you how to use weapons?
No nothing. They just made us sit down all the time."
SUPER CAPTION: Child guerrilla

But others fought voluntarily, even though they are still young.

This man said he was never forced but that he was told he would have to stay with the FARC for at least three years.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"They never threatened us. They never came to me with lies and they never told me I was obliged to go. They said it was voluntary and after 3 or 4 years I could leave if I wanted. "
SUPER CAPTION:  Captured Guerilla

Colombia's civil war has been going on for over 30 years.

Rebels from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia  maintain a strong presence in the Andes mountains south of Bogota and often carry out abductions for ransom and drug trafficking as a way to finance their operations.

The government is trying to engage the group in peace talks while still actively fighting the insurgency.

title: Roland – FARC-EP, el guerrillero que entregó el fusil y ahora preside los lisiados de la guerra
creator: Dick Emanuelsson
description:
Por Dick & Miriam Emanuelsson
Video: 

EL CONEJO-GUAJIRA / 170509 / Punto Transitorio de Normalización “Amaury Rodríguez” en Pondores, La Guajira / En este punto de concentración de guerrilleros de los frentes 19, 41 y 59, más el cordón de seguridad del comandante Iván Márquez, conversamos con el ex combatiente Roland. En julio de 2012 lo entrevistamos [https://youtu.be/WFEbcK2E5pw] sin saber que tres meses después saldría la noticia que decía que las Farc comenzaran un diálogo para llegar a un acuerdo de paz casi cinco años después.
Roland es uno de 500-1000 guerrilleros que han sido herido en el lago conflicto social y armado en Colombia y que han tenido que ver cuando una parte de su cuerpo ha sido mutilado por las bombas u otras armas. Pero se acabó la guerra para Roland y sus compañeros y compañeras y esta ansioso de iniciar una nueva vida.
Preside una nueva Fundación constituida por lisiados de guerra. Pero dice que no solo quiere limitar la nueva organización a los x combatientes de las Farc sino a sus viejos adversarios como paramilitares o incluso militares, aunque las FFMM tienen un excelente hospital en donde no ha ingresado ningún soldado herido o muerto en combate durante 2017.
Pero ¿como se siente Roland ante esa nueva situación, después 21 años en la montañas y selvas?
– La vida ha cambiado mucho ahora. Cero preocupaciones de persecuciones o bombardeo. Yo creo que igual que nosotros los integrantes del ejército pues también han cambiado porque no debe preocuparse que los vamos a buscar, que va haber enfrentamientos y hostigamientos. Yo creo que la paz ha beneficiado a todo el mundo, tanto guerrilleros como militares e incluso población civil. Pero, porque no decirlo, sectores económicos que nunca pudieron llegar a invertir en las áreas donde estuvimos nosotros por situaciones de la guerra.  Pero ahora me imagino que tienen toda vía libre para hacer esto. Ojala piensen en los recursos naturales y en las repercusiones en algunas cosas que tengan del país o el mismo planeta.
– La idea de éste tránsito es llegar a una paz estable y duradera, que no haya persecuciones más delante sino que esto realmente sea sincero y que sea un compromiso, no solamente entre la guerrilla y gobierno sino de todo el pueblo en general que al final es el mayor beneficiado con la terminación del conflicto.
‘El Hospital Militar es ahora un hospital de paz’, escribía Sandra Inés Henao, esposa del general Javier Flórez, integrante en la Comisión Técnica en las negociaciones de paz entre las Farc y el gobierno. En una carta publicada en el diario El Tiempo, celebra que no lleguen más heridos por la guerra:
“Si me hubieran dicho hace 3 años que en el Hospital Militar iban a dejar de llegar algún día heridos en combate, habría dicho: sí claro, claro. ¡Claro! Mi hospital militar era el hospital de la guerra, del dolor, de la lucha. ¡De los milagros! Donde traían a nuestros soldados en pedazos y reconstruían sus cuerpos con amor, magia, profesionalismo, inventando y aprendiendo cómo salvar cada vida que llegaba extinguiéndose. Cada semana, cuando salía de mi visita como dama protectora, le decía a mi familia: mañana no voy a poder levantarme y necesito urgentemente que por favorcito inventen un Dolex para el alma. Cada miércoles, mi corazón se sorprendía porque no podía creer que el ser humano pudiera regenerar su espíritu después de perder tantas partes de su cuerpo. ¡De su mente! Me maravillaba ver esas madres, esposas, familiares continuar cada día con tanto amor para sacar adelante, en una batalla magnánima, a sus seres amados. Era para mí increíble ver sonreír esos niños de 19, 20, 24 años, a veces sin cara, sin ojos, sin manos, sin dientes. ¡Sin piernas! Pero, ¡con una esperanza! Abracé tantos héroes mutilados, tantas familias. Abracé a los que recibían mis abrazos y luche hasta lograr abrazar a los que no querían recibirlos. Abracé a sus madres, padres, hermanos, hijos. Sin decir ni una palabra”.
“En 2016 recibimos solo 36 heridos en combate y en 2017, ninguno!
¡Ninguno!
¡Ninguno!
¡Dios mío! Lloré”.
Roland calcula que son 500-1000 lisiados ex combatientes con amputaciones en las Farc, de los 8.000 guerrilleros, incluyendo los combatientes encarcelados. Como el guerrillero en Combita, Boycá que tiene ambas manos amputadas y que esta ciego.

title: COLUMBIA: REBELS CLAIM CONTROL OF CHOACHI VILLAGE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(28 May 1995) Spanish/Nat

Colombian rebels on Saturday claimed control of a town just 45 kilometers from the capital Bogota.

These are rebels from the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces, or FARC, who had just taken the village of Choachi, only 45 kilometers from the capital, Bogota.

The action is part of a rebel offensive aimed at pressing the government into starting negotiations with the guerrilla movement.

Even though Choachi is very close to Bogota, the rebels had plenty of time to celebrate their victory having a few beers and holding a press conference with reporters from the capital.

A rebel leader offered his conditions to begin the dialogue with the government.

SOUNDBITE: What the government should do is stop their offensive against us. That is the only way we will start talking with them."
SUPER CAPTION: FARC Rebel Leader

The attack is part of several skirmishes by the rebels around the capital, a show of force that is convincing many Colombians that the rebel movements are a force to reckon with.

Thousands of people have died in Colombia in the last three decades since leftist guerrilla groups started their armed struggle against the government.

title: COLOMBIA: SIMITI: ATTACK ON POLICE STATION LEAVES 3 OFFICERS DEAD
creator: AP Archive
description:
(2 Jul 1997) Spanish/Nat

Three police officers have been killed in an attack on a police station in the isolated town of Simiti, 200 miles (322 kilometres) north of Colombia's capital, Bogota.

A police force of 20 officers fought off a rocket and mortar attack led by 300 armed guerrillas during an eleven-hour siege.

The guerrillas, believed to be members of the National Liberation Army (E-L-N), also attacked local residents and abducted two women, including a police officer's wife.

All but three of Simiti's 20-strong police force emerged alive from the wreckage of their bombed-out station on Tuesday morning.

The death toll in this rural outpost in the mountains north of Bogota, seemed low given the details of a siege which have since emerged.

More than 300 armed guerrillas of the Colombian rebel organisation, the National Liberation Army (E-L-N) attacked the station shortly after nightfall on Monday.

The police fought for their lives, with virtually no military assistance, as their station came under rocket and mortar fire.

A further 12 officers were injured.

The guerrillas also abducted two women, an officer's wife and the station's cook, before going on to attack a nearby bank and several public buildings.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"The truth is that, thanks to my men, we were prepared psychologically in every aspect of combat and ammunition. We went to war and we demonstrated what we were capable of because we were in the national police. We can fight, we are few, but we are tough."
SUPER CAPTION: Cesar Moreno, Simiti station commander

There were fears the siege would continue until all 20 police officers were dead and the town had been razed to the ground.

Military sources countered complaints that urgent calls for military assistance went unheeded, and said help was sent as soon as reports of the attack came in.

But counter-guerrilla forces only arrived in Simiti towards midday, Tuesday, to find scenes of devastation left in the guerrillas' wake.

Eye witnesses say the E-L-N troops had poured in on foot and in trucks.

The town's electricity supplies and telephone wires were cut off prior to the launch of the attack, shortly after nightfall.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is what happened. Bombs, bombs, exploding. I couldn't do anything. When a grenade arrived it went off in the kitchen, the table burst into little pieces. I went with my brothers to look for the children. I was with the young one that I had and I stayed by him."
SUPER CAPTION: Ester Munoz, witness to the attack

In the siege which followed, the survivors estimated more than five- thousand shots were fired, along with dynamite.

The purpose of the attack is not yet clear but it is just the latest clash in Colombia's on-going guerrilla war.

title: COLOMBIA: BARRANCABERMEJA: PROTESTS CONTINUE AFTER MASSACRE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(7 Jun 1998) Spanish/Nat

Protests continued in Barrancabermeja, Colombia, on Saturday following news of a  mass slaughter in which 25 men and women died. 

The victims had been executed by a paramilitary group for alleged rebel activity though  human rights activists say army and police units were also involved.

A rebel spokesman has vowed to avenge their deaths. 

The 25 coffins by a roadside in this oil refining city north of Bogota are dedicated to the  latest victims of Colombian violence.

A sad reminder that Barrancabermeja, home to 240-thousand, is trapped in the bloody  crossfire.

The dead disappeared last month and were later executed by a right-wing paramilitary  group - the so-called United Self-Defence Group of Colombia (A-U-C).

Human rights activists say that army and police units abetted the kidnapping. 

Witnesses claim security forces were at the scene of the assault
moments before 50 masked gunmen entered a poor neighborhood, killed seven people  and carted away 25 others in trucks.

But local army and police chiefs have denied involvement in the crime. 

Investigations are underway but the families of the dead remain in shock.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"My sons were never those kinds of people. We are humble, hardworking people. We  are not bad people like these types. My son was never any kind of rebel. That was  never the case, you couldn't say that." 
Q: "The paramilitaries say they killed them because they were involved with the  guerrillas."
A: "No sir. That is a false lie." 
SUPER CAPTION: Alfonso, father of one of the dead 

Maria, wife of one of the dead, still hopes for news that her husband is alive. 

But the paramilitary group responsible for his capture confirmed on Thursday that all 25  had been first tried and later executed.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"A young man who only dedicated himself to his work, his home. He didn't have any  problems with anybody. They took him and until now, nobody knows anything. So we  want to ask if they are still holding them alive that they return them to us, that they (the  prisoners) take heart because their captors also have families and they know what it is  like to lose somebody close to you. And if they are dead, that they hand them (the  bodies) over. What can we do? They have to hand them over, alive or dead, please hand  them over."
SUPER CAPTION: Maria, wife of one of the dead

The dead were accused of working closely with the E-L-N (National Liberation Army)  and E-P-L (Popular Liberation Army).

A spokesman for the E-L-N denied this was the case. 

But he also vowed the paramilitaries and any associated groups would pay for this  mistake. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"We make it very clear that all these commanders are military targets. The fundamental  idea is to exercise a revolutionary justice over them and we will apply it with all the  rigour that our abilities allow - those guilty of this massacre. And we have to say to  them that they got it wrong. We must tell Ernesto Samper's government, the defence  minister, and the chief of armed forces that they all got it wrong, that they have not  assassinated any rebel member of the E-L-N or the E-P-L. They were civilians. They will  have to pay for their deaths. And most certainly they will be made to pay."
SUPER CAPTION: Rafael, E-L-N Commander 

His declaration prolongs the likelihood of continued war within and around  Barrancabermeja.

This, despite a three week civil protest for peace which culminated in strike action. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
SUPER CAPTION: Rafael, E-L-N Commander

title: COLOMBIA: PACHO: COMMUNE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(2 Nov 2000) Spanish/Nat 
XFA
Almost four months ago, a young Irish boy who grew up in a commune in Colombia was  killed by Colombia's largest rebel group, the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia,  or FARC. 

His grandmother, Jenny James, was a pacifist who founded the commune on which he  lived 11 years ago. 

Now, James says that she is seeking justice for her grandson and she wants to see  that his death is avenged. 

This farm seems like a piece of paradise. 

Tucked away in the countryside about 50 kilometres away from Colombia's capital  Bogota, the people here live at one with nature. 

The girls go and plant and harvest vegetables every day. 

They eat mainly what they grow. 

The commune has dwindled to about a dozen people - but the group has been in  Colombia for about 11 years, living in different areas of the country. 

Jenny James left her native England, went to Ireland, and founded the commune in  Colombia after wandering through Latin America. 

As a devoted ecologist and anti-nuclear activist she wanted to be as far away from the  city as possible. 

But the commune began to have difficulties several months ago when members were  thrown off the land they were living by a local FARC commander. 

They then moved to the place where they are now. 

James' grandson, 18-year-old Tristan, and another Colombian friend returned to the  village on July 9 to see his half-brother who had been left behind with a local family. 

That was when the problems began. 

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
" The leaders of the gang got themselves very drunk, and as soon as they saw our boys  returning from their visit to my grandson, they came at them, they chased them, into  the middle of a football match, everyone ran away screaming, didn't help our boys, as  far as we know our boys were captured and they had their hands tied behind their  backs, and they were taken to a room and we don't know what happened in that room,  and then they were taken out further down the road, and as far as we know our  grandson was crying, and they slit his throat." 
SUPERCAPTION: Jenny James, grandmother of murdered boy 

Tristan's friend was also decapitated and both their bodies were doused with gasoline  and burned. 

Tristan was an actor in local troupes which put on performances about ecological  themes. 

Like most of the children here, he had never had any formal education. 

He was just about to return to Ireland to 'discover his roots' when the tragedy happened.  
James squarely blames the FARC for his death. 

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
" We are doing what we can but at the moment the latest block that we've met is that  the local commander who was the one who chucked us out, who is as far as we are  concerned a very non-political and very violent and very stupid man, and who more or  less caused these deaths and even ordered them, he has now become the head of the  25 Front of the FARC. Which organises the area where all this occured, and to go there  at the moment would be to invite total tragedy for all of us. 
SUPERCAPTION:Jenny James, grandmother of murdered boy 

James's political leaning's would have previously lead her to support a peasant based  rebel movement like the FARC. 

She initially had wanted to take the commune to Bolivia because that was were Che  Guevara had died. 

But now she says that she considers the FARC murderers and wants to use her  grandson's death to publicise what is happening here. 


James's daughter and another member of the commune wrote this song to  commemorate the two young men's deaths.

title: COLOMBIA: EL CALVARIO HOME TO THE FARC REBELS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(3 Apr 1998) Spanish/Nat

The rugged jungle of Colombia conceals one of the most active and violent guerrilla  movements of the southern hemisphere.

El Calvario, in Meta province, 75 kilometres south-east of Bogota, is home to one of the  fronts of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). 

Their struggle and the ensuing conflict has cost thousands of lives in recent years,  despite sporadic attempts at peace.

Dawn breaks over a FARC rebel camp on the outskirts of El Calvario, a mountain village  75 kilometres outside the capital Bogota.

The men and women here are part of a rebel organisation that has engaged in 30-years  of battle with Colombia's government. 

Camps such as these are run according to strict military discipline and the results  show. 

FARC remains the most powerful rebel group in the country and has shown ruthless  efficiency in the battlefield. 

Its southern block is made up of eleven fronts, stationed across the departments of  Caqueta, Guaviare, Putumayo, Huila and Narino.

Its infrastructure consists mainly of small groups, and mostly of young rural labourers in  their twenties, fighting for what they believe is equality and democracy.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"Since I was a child I wanted to fight as part of a guerrilla group because of the political,  economical and social crisis that existed in the country."
SUPER CAPTION: Eduardo Guerrero, FARC rebel

President Ernesto Samper's government says these rebels are criminals, motivated by  profits from kidnapping, narco-trafficking and extortion rather than political ideas.

The rebels, in return, do not acknowledge a government plagued by corruption. 

In addition, rural poverty provides a fertile ground for new rebel recruits.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
Q: " Why did you get involved in guerrilla action?"
A: "Because I liked it. When I got in I wasn't conscious of the struggle, but when you  are here you realize the struggle."
SUPER CAPTION: Elizabeth, FARC rebel

The guerrillas exert control over vast areas of rural Colombia and frequently enlist  youngsters desperate for a better life.

Men are not the only ones to enroll.

Some women, too, consider it an honour to be part of the rebel movement.

SOUNDBITE:(Spanish) 
Q: "How old are you?"
A: "I am nineteen years old."
Q: "Since when have you been fighting with the FARC?"
A: "I've been here six years." (Cut away to rifle and knife)
Q: "How do you feel, being a woman guerrilla?"
A: "I feel good."
Q: "Why?"
A: "It feels an honour, because there are few girls here. This is a hard life." 
Q: "Why did you decide to be a guerrilla?"
A: "First of all I liked it, and the other thing is that sometimes you suffer at home, then  you have to choose this life, which is very good."
SUPER CAPTION: Maribel, FARC rebel

There is no accurate figure on the numbers active in the FARC.

Funding is attributed to the FARC's links with narco-trafficking.

This cash has helped the FARC develop into an effective fighting force and a match for  rural government military outposts.

title: COLOMBIA: PRESIDENT SAMPER ORDERS OFFENSIVE AGAINST REBELS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(1 Jun 1995) STORY
Spanish/Nat
Colombian president Ernesto Samper has ordered a full-scale offensive against rebel forces locked in combat with his government.
Over the past four days rebels have launched a violent campaign in which more than 40 people have been killed.
The heating up of the three-decade long conflict is making peace negotiations look increasingly shaky.
APTV was with a corps of elite soldiers when they dealt a major blow against the guerrillas by seizing a camp belonging to the powerful Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
These four suspected guerrillas were captured by the army when they raided a large guerrilla camp hidden in the mountainous and thickly forested department of Boyaca, north of the capital Bogota.
Four suspected guerrillas and one soldiers were killed in a fierce firefight when the army attacked this camp belonging to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
According to the Colombian military, it is the second largest rebel camp taken by the army.
Seventeen tons of supplies were seized from the camp, among them quantities of propaganda material.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is an important blow on behalf of the country. What we're doing is maintaining the stability of the country and that's important. This a very important part of the country. It's an oil producing area. It's the heart of the country's economy. So this a blow the army has dealt for the country."
SUPER CAPTION: Major Reyes
The Cuban-inspired FARC is the oldest and largest of Colombia's guerrilla groups. For three decades it has been locked in combat with successive governments.
It and the Maoist National Liberation Army are engaged in preliminary peace talks with the government.
In an upsurge of guerrilla violence, police and army patrols have been ambushed and, increasingly, the rebels have launched attacks from the large slums surrounding the capital.
Yesterday (Wednesday) three policemen were killed and two others injured in a guerrilla attack in the middle class Bogota suburb of Kennedy.
The army is now concentrating its resources on the mountainous area to the north and east of the capital where FARC forces have recently launched several ambushes on the security forces.

STORYLINE:

Colombian army troops continue to reclaim territory that's been under rebel control for over three years.

It's been four days since peace talks between the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, and the government came to an abrupt end.

Government forces have been painstakingly moving forward into the region and restoring constitutional law and order one town at a time.

In the town of Vista Hermosa, in Meta Province, approximately 350 kilometres east of Bogota, inhabitants waited eagerly for the soldiers' arrival.  

Once an important stronghold of guerrilla forces, Vista Hermosa witnessed their quick retreat when the airforce began bombing nearby camps on the night of February 21.

The army will maintain a large presence until further notice.

The airforce continues to bomb camps and installations belonging to the rebel FARC group. 

150 (90 miles) kilometres east of San Vicente del Caguan, government forces bombed a rebel airstrip, dropping three large bombs. 

The government says the airstrip was being used for drug-trafficking. 

The rebels are refusing to leave the enclave which was ceded to them by President Andres Pastrana in 1998. 

Pastrana called off peace talks and ordered the army to retake the zone after guerrillas hijacked an airplane and kidnapped a current senator on Wednesday.

STORYLINE:

Some estimates say that women make up 40 per cent of Colombia's largest rebel group - the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

They fight in combat, live and work with their male counterparts and on the surface suffer no discrimination.

But female guerrillas admit it's not an easy life.

Once admitted to the FARC, women are given monthly injections of birth control drugs to stop them getting pregnant.

If they do get pregnant, they often give their children away to be cared for by their families far from the front lines.

Even relationships are monitored and female guerrillas say if they want to have a serious relationship with a man they must ask for their commander's permission.

While this might seem like life in a regular army, fighting with the FARC is a lifetime commitment.

The women say they're committed to social justice and will lay down their life for their cause.

But while women make up a substantial number of the FARC, there are still relatively few female high commanders.

They come from poor rural backgrounds where traditional roles force women into subordination.

A lack of education - many cannot read or write - prevents them from important decision-making.

Despite the rhetoric of comradeship and equality there's often no getting away from the age-old Latin American machismo which organises power relations in every area of society.

En esa época, año de 1985, había un grupo guerrillero llamado “Frente Ricardo Franco”, que decían ser disidentes de las FARC (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia), lo cual era negado por ellos. Años después, descubrió Raúl Benoit, que los hombres armados eran paramilitares o autodefensas al servicio de empresarios y la sociedad elitista. El jefe del “Frente Ricardo Franco”, era alías Javier Delgado, a quien lo vio Benoit, años después de la entrevista, entrar a un cuartel militar en Bogotá.    

"La Matanza de Tacueyó" fue uno de los más atroces crímenes de la violencia en Colombia. Mataron a más de 264 subversivos. Ocurrió en diciembre de 1985 en el Departamento del Cauca, hechos por estos paramilitares.   

Raúl Benoit revela todo el material, con las entrevistas y el video sin censura, para que usted juzgue.

Los autores fueron alias Javier Delgado (cuyo nombre real era José Fedor Rey) y Hernando Pizarro Leongómez, los dos asesinados en hechos oscuramente. Pizarro era hermano de Carlos Pizarro Leongómez, el comandante del M 19,  que no tenían conexión con él.

En el libro “Prohibido Decir Toda la Verdad”, Raúl Benoit narra esta historia. Lo puede encontrar en Amazon punto com.

title: COLOMBIA: LOS ALPES: REBELS FREE LAST 4 AMERICAN HOSTAGES
creator: AP Archive
description:
(26 Apr 1998) Spanish/Nat

Leftist rebels on Saturday freed the last of four Americans kidnapped while on a bird- watching expedition a month ago.

The handover of the two men came just a day after rebels of the Revolutionary Armed  Forces of Colombia released another of the men's colleagues.

Peter Shen and Todd Mark appeared to be in good health and said their captors had  treated them well.

The last of four American birdwatchers abducted by Colombian rebels a month ago  walked to freedom on Saturday.

Peter Shen and Todd Mark were handed over to journalists about an hour's walk from  Los Alpes, an Andean mountain town 60 miles south of the capital, Bogota.

Considering their ordeal, the two seemed to be in good condition. 

They were even cracking jokes. One of the hostages told waiting journalists that he had  bored his abductors by talking to them about birds.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"Yes of course I am now relieved because I had no idea how long I was going to be  kept. I was ready to be held captive for a year because who knows (how things turn  out). It was completely out of my hands. I thought they were holding me for some sort  of political reason -- who knows? But I came here only as a bird-watcher. It seems  crazy to everyone but what can I do."
SUPER CAPTION: Todd Mark, released hostage

Both men said the rebels had treated them well.

SOUNDBITE: (English)
Peter Shen: "I think for security we were handcuffed at night when we slept".
Todd Mark: "Most of the things were arranged so that we wouldn't escape, we wouldn't  attempt to escape".
Peter Shen: "We wouldn't attempt to escape but otherwise they treated us very well".
Todd Mark: "Actually, it was, if anything I would say security was liberal sometimes".
Peter Shen: "Yes, that's right".
SUPER CAPTION: Peter Shen and Todd Mark, released hostages

Their release followed the freeing on Friday of a third hostage, Louise Augustine, 63, a  retired school teacher and former nun from Chillicothe, Illinois.

The FARC also took about two dozen Colombians captive, but have released most of  them.

The Americans were abducted while trying to spot a rare bird called the Cundinamarca  Antpitta. 

The bird is only found in the region south of Bogota, Colombia's capital.

The remote mountainous region is a hotbed for rebel kidnapping activity.

Colombia has the planet's greatest diversity of birds but also leads the world in  kidnappings, with nearly four abductions a day.

A fourth kidnapped bird-watcher, Thomas Fiore, was found April 2 by a television crew  doing a report on the abductions. 

He says he escaped, but rebels insist they let him go.

Foreigners are prized targets because they often fetch higher ransoms. 

It was not clear if a ransom was paid for these hostages.

A FARC commander said they had been held because they were investigating if the  group were U-S government agents.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"We kept them for about a month while we investigated whether or not they had any  links with intelligence agents."
SUPER CAPTION:  Marko Aurelio, FARC Commander

As the freed Americans and journalists walked down a mountain to waiting government  and Red Cross representatives, an explosion rocked the path about 300 metres (900  feet) from them. 

More mortar fire could be heard in the distance.

A local army commander claimed that rebels attacked an army patrol near the release  site and were returning fire.

The two headed for the Red Cross where they were given a cursory health check.


Both men were expected to leave on Sunday or Monday for the United States.

title: COLOMBIA: BOGOTA: CAR BOMB EXPLODES IN BUSY STREET
creator: AP Archive
description:
(11 Nov 1999) Spanish/Nat 

A powerful car bomb has exploded in a busy street in an upmarket part of the Colombian capital, Bogota, killing six people and injuring at least twelve others. 

The bomb, apparently placed in a green Renault car, destroyed a house and a restaurant and blew out the windows of banks, hotels and seven-storey apartment buildings 50 metres across the street.

No armed group has claimed responsibility for the bombing so far, although there is growing speculation that drug-traffickers are behind the attack. 

For the second time this week, a car bomb has exploded in the Colombian capital, Bogota.

The powerful bomb ripped through a residential area in the north of the city, killing six people and injuring at least 12 others. 

The bomb, apparently containing ten kilogrammes of dynamite, left a one-metre-deep crater in the street.  

There was also extensive damage to nearby houses and cars.

One of the wounded described what happened.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"There was an explosion. I don't know what happened and when I opened the door the whole thing blew up. We don't know anything more than that. It looks like the bomb was just over there. I have been injured but I can't leave my house because they will loot it." 
SUPER CAPTION: Francisco, Car bomb victim

The mayor of Bogota said the bomb could be a response to a government move against drug traffickers. 

Colombia has again decided to start extraditing alleged drug traffickers to the United States.

The Supreme Court ruled this week that the extradition of two alleged drug-traffickers, a Colombian and a Venezuelan, could take place.

It's now up to the government of President Andres Pastrana to give the go-ahead. 

The Colombian authorities have offered a 50-thousand U-S dollar reward to anybody offering information that could lead to the arrest of the perpetrators.

title: COLOMBIA: MILITARY SACKS NEARLY 400 OFFICERS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(17 Oct 2000) Spanish/Nat 

The Colombian military has sacked nearly 400 officers and soldiers in the biggest ever purge of the armed forces. 

It has denied this was in response to U-S pressure to improve their human rights records. 

The U-S government's 1.3 (b) billion U-S dollar contribution to Pastrana's Plan Colombia comes on the condition that progress be made on human rights violations. 

Military powers to dismiss soldiers for misconduct were granted by President Andres Pastrana in September. 

Many human rights groups say U-S money should not be going to the Colombian military because the army is alleged to maintain close ties with outlawed paramilitary death squads. 

Armed forces chief, General Fernando Tapias, said the dismissals were simply an effort to improve the efficiency of the 150 thousand-member forces. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is simply a discretional measure that seeks to strengthen the armed forces, seeks to strengthen their cohesion, to have absolute integrity and transparency throughout the armed forces and to give them a sense of professionalism."
SUPER CAPTION: General Fernando Tapias,  Armed Forces chief

The Colombian Defence Minister, Luis Fernando Ramirez has been evasive about why the 89 officers and the 299 rank-and-file members of the army, navy and air force had been dismissed but in a press conference he was adamant that the decision was not influenced by external factors.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This has absolutely nothing to do with recommendations or suggestions from any foreign government. This is an absolutely autonomous decision. Absolutely nobody knows the officers and soldiers listed at the moment, only the armed forces and the government know. Other Colombian organisations will know later but it doesn't respond to any suggestion or solicitation from any foreign government or any other organisation. It is an eminently autonomous decision. As General Tapias said, what we want to achieve by this decision, which is historic and which has never been taken before in the armed forces, is that from here emerges a much more solid, professional and modern armed forces."
SUPER CAPTION: Luis Fernando Ramirez, Colombian Defence Minister

Pastrana's U-S backed Plan Colombia is unpopular with Colombians and international groups alike.

Plan Colombia is an initiative aimed at wiping out drug trafficking from Colombia and strengthening its democracy. 

Activists and local Colombian officials object to the program, saying it focuses too much on the military aspect and will intensify the civil war.

They criticise the government for agreeing to U-S suggestions in order to receive their financial help at the expense of the true needs of local people.

title: COLOMBIA: FARC REBELS CLASH WITH GOVERNMENT TROOPS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(21 Jun 1998) Spanish/Nat

Marxist rebels fought pitched battles with government troops on Saturday on a highway east of the capital, with reports that they set fire to more than 20 vehicles.

The fighting lasted all day and spilled into Sunday as the troubled, volatile country went to the polls in the Presidential elections.

Motorists caught in the crossfire were forced to abandon their cars and run for cover.

The latest fighting broke out about 70 kilometers (44 miles) east of the Colombian capital, Bogota, on the main highway near Villavicencio.

FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia) guerillas opened fire.

Government soldiers answered with a hail of bullets triggering a fierce gun battle.

The fighting lasted all day, Saturday, with reports that one soldier was wounded.

Sporadic clashes flared up through much of Sunday, despite government efforts to ensure a peaceful day at the polls by deploying 200-thousand troops.

The FARC is reportedly trying to discourage voters from going to the polls.

The armed group had called for a transportation strike, and then on Saturday blocked off this road.

Motorists along the busy highway were caught unawares - trapped in the middle of a raging gun battle.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"What can I do?  I have no choice.  I just have to try to keep on driving through."
SUPER CAPTION: Vox Pop, Truck Driver

Caught in the crossfire, there was nothing these people could do except dive for cover - their vehicles were their only shields from stray bullets.

The FARC has been waging a war of attrition against the Colombian state for more than three decades.

During the tenure of outgoing president Ernesto Samper violence from both leftist guerrillas and extreme-right paramilitaries worsened.

title: COLOMBIA: ELN & FARC REBEL GROUPS TO JOIN FORCES
creator: AP Archive
description:
(30 Sep 1998) Spanish/Nat 

The two largest left-wing rebel groups in Colombia have decided to work together in the fight against growing right wing paramilitary activity.

The ELN (The National Liberation Army), Colombia's second largest guerrilla group is to join forces with the FARC (The Colombian Armed Forces) for the first time ever.

Paramilitary forces have recently been making a push to gain control of the northeast oil-producing regions from their enemies, the leftist rebels.

The ELN's main rallying cry is against the foreign exploitation of Colombia's natural resources.

On the Magdalena river one can frequently see the smoke from the oil pipeline which is often blown up by ELN rebels.

But, the ELN, which has been losing ground in Serrania de San Lucas in the south of Bolivar state, is now joining forces with the larger and better equipped FARC.

FARC is approximately three times larger than the ELN.

On the face of it, those suffering most from the recent outbursts of violence are the civilians and shopkeepers.

Many have closed down completely.

But, despite the two rebel forces joining forces, the ELN has not renounced all intentions to negotiate a peace treaty with the Pastrana government.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"We have said up to today that we are not going to hand in our weapons. We thinks that we can also be part of the new security forces of the state we want to build between all of us."
SUPER CAPTION:  Comandante Danilo, of ELN Bloque Comandante Parmenio

The FARC and the ELN have never publicly admitted to working together before -but both sides seem equally sure it will work. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"We, the FARC, here in the south of Bolivar are working together with the ELN to sort out the situation here in the south of Bolivar."
SUPER CAPTION: Commander Pedro, 39th Front of FARC

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"We have joined forces to attack all the paramilitaries in south of Bolivar and ELN and FARC have joined forces to do that."
SUPER CAPTION: Commander Darwin, ELN

Whether the latest initiative between the rebel forces will help end Colombia's 34 year civil war no one can predict.

For the moment it seems neither side is showing any signs of letting up.

title: COLOMBIA: MONFORT: VILLAGERS CAUGHT IN CROSSFIRE OF A BLOODY WAR
creator: AP Archive
description:
(7 Apr 1998) Spanish/Nat

Residents of Monfort, a remote Colombian village, are caught in the crossfire of a bloody war. 

The village lies 150 kilometers from the capital Bogota, in mountains where fighting between government, paramilitary and rebel troops is frequent.

A semblance of normal life revolves around the local dairy farm, church and village square but the 300 people who live there live in fear.

Rebel troops stand vigilant outside the tiny village of Monfort.

The village lies in mountains 150 kilometers outside Colombia's capital Bogota.

It is home to some 300 people and an unwelcome conflict that has brought fear into their lives.

The surrounding dense forest and undergrowth is a battleground for government, paramilitary and rebel troops - among them the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"The Americans - as I said before - not (will not be freed) until we get orders from the central command. As for the Italian, it will be based on the investigation - whether some of them have links with the American Central Intelligence Agency and the FBI."
SUPER CAPTION: Eduardo, FARC rebel

The town is not recognised as a hotbed of support for any of the warring factions. 

It is simply a frontline. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"For a long time the U-S have been meddling in the affairs and I think that they are practically helping the paramilitary groups and military forces with armaments, fighter planes, combat planes, and they are practically linked to this war that we have in Colombia."
SUPER CAPTION: Eduardo, FARC rebel

The families who live here maintain a sense of normality. 

Many work at the local dairy farm. 

The village has one church, whose newly appointed priest replaced a predecessor shot dead last year by unknown assassins.

Some 30-40 houses stand around the village square.

A pall of desolation hangs over a community devoid of government investment and with limited infrastructure. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"We feel under pressure by the armed forces, both the guerrillas and the army. We are a small village where we live very peaceful lives. We don't want any trouble." 
SUPER CAPTION: Roman Cerritos, villager

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"We are peasants and we feel that we are stuck in this dreadful situation. It's like being between two walls, two walls."
SUPER CAPTION: Flor Isabel, villager

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"It is something that we have to in this case pray for God to protect us because we are in the middle of chaos. We are mounted on all sides by the guerrillas and by the army."
SUPER CAPTION: Edgar Velasquez, villager

One road leads into Monfort.

Many must walk for hours between here and the nearest market towns. 

But the fate of those who live here, oppressed by years of conflict, is shared by thousands of other Colombians and their hope is for peace.

title: Catorce guerrilleros de las FARC murieron en un operativo de las fuerzas militares en el noreste de
creator: AP Archive
description:
(21 Jan 2014) Catorce guerrilleros de las FARC murieron en un operativo de las fuerzas militares en el noreste de Colombia, informaron las autoridades el lunes.
El ejercito mostro los cadaveres de los guerrilleros a la prensa. 
SOUNDBITE - General Leonardo Barrero, Comandante de la fuerza aerea
"La fuerza aerea efect�a un ataque inicialmente donde posteriormente ingresan tropas del ejercito nacional y realizados los registros encontramos 14 cadaveres pertenecientes a la estructura Alfonso Castellanos de las FARC. A su vez, se encontro un guerrillero herido, Fue atendido oportunamente, y uno 
mas desmovilizado para un total de 16 neutralizaciones".
La accion se produjo el domingo por la madrugada en zona rural del municipio de Puerto Rondon, unos 380 kilometros al noreste de Bogota. 
Seg�n un comunicado de las fuerzas militares, los insurgentes muertos pertenecian a la columna movil "Alfonso Castellanos" de las Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia . 
Seg�n las autoridades esa columna rebelde y su cabecilla, conocido con el alias de 'Franklin', son los responsables de m�ltiples acciones terroristas en contra de la poblacion civil y de la fuerza p�blica. 
Las autoridades tambien mostraron a la prensa armas que fueron incautadas durante el operativo.
Actualmente, el gobierno del presidente Juan Manuel Santos y las rebeldes FARC adelantan en Cuba un proceso de paz para tratar de poner fin a 50 anos de confrontaciones entre las partes.
El proceso comenzo a fines del 2012 y este lunes, el presidente dijo que cree que en el 2014 se firmara la paz con las FARC.
Las delegaciones del gobierno y de la guerrilla han dicho que ya llegaron a acuerdos en los puntos 1 y 2 de la agenda: tema agrario y participacion politica y ciudadana
Las partes ahora discuten el punto referente a la solucion al problema de las drogas ilicitas. La agenda pactada tiene seis puntos.
